newsitem.title: TUNISIA: Arafat urges Arabs to oppose Israel on settlements.
newsitem.headline: Arafat urges Arabs to oppose Israel on settlements.

text.p: Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on Friday called on Arab and Moslem countries to take steps to force Israel to stop building Jewish settlements in and around Arab East Jerusalem.

"These things...call for a quick Palestinian, Arab and Moslem move to face these dangerous developments not only against Jerusalem but also against the Palestinian people....," he told reporters after briefing Tunisian President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali on the crisis in the Middle East peace process.
Arafat said such moves would be based on previous decisions at Moslem and Arab summit meetings.
Resolutions adopted in Islamabad and Cairo last year threatened to freeze diplomatic ties established by some Arab and Moslem states with Israel.
Arafat accused Israel of aiming, through Jewish settlements, to cut Arab East Jerusalem off from Palestinian territories in the West Bank.
"I told President Ben Ali that despite these difficulties, we will pray together in Jerusalem, capital of the Palestinian state," he added.

Earlier Arafat's spokesman Marwan Kanafani said that Arafat, who arrived in Tunis on Friday, would fly to Gaza immediately after meeting Ben Ali, where he was expected to chair a cabinet meeting of the Palestinian self-rule Authority.
But Arafat instead went to his Tunis headquarters where he lived in exile for 10 years until returning to Gaza following the 1993 Palestinian-Israeli peace deal.

Palestinian officials said Arafat headed a meeting with Tunis-based Palestinian leaders still in exile and was to leave later on Friday. Arafat was in Rabat on Thursday where he met U.S. Middle East peace envoy Dennis Ross.
